title: 115_s1103
content: The Department of Homeland Security Blue Campaign Authorization Act of 2017 enhances coordination through the Blue Campaign within the Department of Homeland Security. The Blue Campaign, established within the Department of Homeland Security, aims to unify and coordinate efforts to address human trafficking. The program is headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary, who is responsible for issuing guidance, developing training programs, and coordinating departmental efforts. The Blue Campaign provides guidance and training to Department personnel and other law enforcement agencies on identifying human trafficking instances, collecting relevant information, and sharing information among agencies. The Blue Campaign provides training on identifying human trafficking, including techniques to identify victims at border and airport security checkpoints, training TSA employees, and utilizing resources like indicator cards and campaigns. The Blue Campaign conducts various awareness activities, such as educational materials and partnerships with organizations, to increase public awareness of human trafficking. Additionally, the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include these activities in the Blue Campaign's mandate. The Secretary of Homeland Security must integrate information technology systems within the Department to track individuals involved in human trafficking within a year of this Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to submit a report on the Department of Homeland Security Blue Campaign within 18 months of this Act's enactment. Additionally, $819,000 is authorized for section 434 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require the Secretary of Homeland Security to issue guidance and develop training programs for the Department of Homeland Security Blue Campaign.
